entries.title: Two-layer spacing system: precision (4pt) + rhythm (8pt)
entries.description: One scale, two layers. Modern design systems don't choose between 4pt or 8pt — they assign responsibility.
entries.example: Precision: Icons, typography baselines, and internal component spacing. Rhythm: Layout spacing, padding, margins, and component sizing

entries.title: Spacing token: micro (4px)
entries.description: Use: Icon ↔ text. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: tight (8px)
entries.description: Use: Label ↔ input. Layer: both

entries.title: Spacing token: compact (12px)
entries.description: Use: Button groups, tight lists. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: base (16px)
entries.description: Use: Within component. Layer: both

entries.title: Spacing token: related (20px)
entries.description: Use: Related content groups. Layer: precision

entries.title: Spacing token: comfortable (24px)
entries.description: Use: Between components. Layer: both

entries.title: Spacing token: spacious (32px)
entries.description: Use: Between sections. Layer: rhythm

entries.title: Spacing token: loose (40px)
entries.description: Use: Major content blocks. Layer: rhythm

entries.title: Spacing token: section (48px)
entries.description: Use: Major sections. Layer: rhythm

entries.title: Spacing token: page (96px)
entries.description: Use: Hero, footer. Layer: rhythm

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Arbitrary values: m-[32px]
entries.description: Tailwind arbitrary values like m-[32px], p-[18px], gap-[22px] bypass the spacing scale and create one-off values that drift from the design system. They are not constrained to the 4px grid, cannot be updated via theme changes, and introduce visual inconsistency. Always use the nearest token: m-[32px] → gap-8, p-[18px] → p-5 (20px) or p-4 (16px). If no token fits, reconsider the design rather than inventing a custom value.
entries.counterExample: m-[32px] → gap-8, p-[18px] → p-5, gap-[22px] → gap-6 (24px)

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Inline styles: style={{ margin: '32px' }}
entries.description: Inline styles for spacing (style={{ margin: '32px', padding: '16px' }}) bypass Tailwind's utility system entirely. They cannot be themed, don't respond to breakpoints, are invisible to design system tooling, and increase CSS specificity unpredictably. Convert to Tailwind classes: style={{ margin: '32px' }} → m-8, style={{ padding: '16px 24px' }} → px-6 py-4. The only exception is truly dynamic values computed at runtime (e.g., positioning a tooltip).
entries.counterExample: style={{ margin: '32px' }} → m-8, style={{ gap: '12px' }} → gap-3

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Breaking 4px grid
entries.description: All spacing values must be multiples of 4px (the precision layer). Values like 5px, 7px, 10px, 13px, or 18px break visual alignment and create subpixel rendering artifacts on non-retina displays. The 4px grid ensures consistent alignment across all components. Valid values: 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, 24, 32, 40, 48, 64, 96px. If a design spec shows a non-4px value, round to the nearest 4px multiple.

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Inconsistent spacing within same context
entries.description: Inconsistent spacing within same context

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Off-grid values: 5px, 7px, 18px, 29px — random values confuse users
entries.description: Off-grid values: 5px, 7px, 18px, 29px — random values confuse users

entries.title: Spacing forbidden: Typography that doesn't snap to 8pt baseline grid
entries.description: Typography that doesn't snap to 8pt baseline grid

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: fillingEveryGap
entries.description: Filling every available gap with content reduces scannability, makes layouts harder to parse, and forces users to work harder to understand structure
entries.why: If everything is filled, nothing stands out
entries.counterExample: Use white space to define grouping, separate content blocks, and clarify intent — leave intentional gaps

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: sectionsBleeding
entries.description: Sections visually bleed into each other when vertical gaps between sections are not significantly larger than gaps within sections
entries.why: Spacing is the primary signal of hierarchy
entries.counterExample: Use section-level tokens (gap-12/gap-16, 48-64px) between sections and smaller tokens (gap-4/gap-6, 16-24px) within sections — the ratio should be at least 2:1

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: crowdingTextBlocks
entries.description: Tight paragraphs and minimal line/section spacing kills readability and increases cognitive load, making long-form content exhausting to read
entries.why: Readability depends more on space than on font choice
entries.counterExample: Increase spacing between paragraphs more than between lines — use mb-4 to mb-6 between paragraphs, leading-relaxed for long-form content

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: overpackingComponents
entries.description: Stuffing cards and components with too many elements (buttons, tags, metadata, badges) increases cognitive load and blurs the component's primary purpose
entries.why: More content does not equal more value — one clear intent per component
entries.counterExample: Remove non-essential elements, use progressive disclosure (expand/detail views), limit cards to: title + description + 1 primary action + 1-2 metadata items

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: inconsistentComponentSpacing
entries.description: Each component inventing its own internal spacing logic makes the system feel fragmented and harder to maintain at scale
entries.why: Components inherit spacing rules from the system — spacing tokens are reused, not improvised
entries.counterExample: Define spacing tokens per component type: cards use p-6, forms use space-y-4, button groups use gap-2 or gap-3 — never ad-hoc values

entries.title: Layout anti-pattern: ignoringVerticalRhythm
entries.description: Treating spacing as purely horizontal while ignoring vertical rhythm makes the interface flow feel erratic and uncomfortable
entries.why: Vertical spacing controls pace, comfort, and flow
entries.counterExample: Establish predictable Y-axis spacing patterns — repeat the same vertical rhythm across sections using the 8pt rhythm layer

entries.title: Spacing principle: Space defines grouping and separates content blocks
entries.description: Space defines grouping and separates content blocks
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: If everything is filled, nothing stands out
entries.description: If everything is filled, nothing stands out
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: Spacing is the primary signal of hierarchy — larger gaps between sections than within sections
entries.description: Spacing is the primary signal of hierarchy — larger gaps between sections than within sections
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: Readability depends more on space than on font choice
entries.description: Readability depends more on space than on font choice
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: Vertical spacing controls pace, comfort, and flow
entries.description: Vertical spacing controls pace, comfort, and flow
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: One clear intent per component — more content does not equal more value
entries.description: One clear intent per component — more content does not equal more value
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: Components inherit spacing rules from the system, not invent their own
entries.description: Components inherit spacing rules from the system, not invent their own
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Spacing principle: White space must scale with screen size
entries.description: White space must scale with screen size
entries.context: White space is not empty — it is an active design tool that creates structure, hierarchy, focus, rhythm, and comfort. Treating space as 'unused' leads to clutter, cognitive overload, and loss of hierarchy.

entries.title: Border radius: none (0px)
entries.description: Use: Sharp edges

entries.title: Border radius: xs (4px)
entries.description: Use: Badges, chips

entries.title: Border radius: sm (8px)
entries.description: Use: Buttons, inputs

entries.title: Border radius: md (12px)
entries.description: Use: Nested containers

entries.title: Border radius: lg (16px)
entries.description: Use: Medium containers

entries.title: Border radius: xl (20px)
entries.description: Use: Cards, dialogs, tables

entries.title: Border radius: 2xl (24px)
entries.description: Use: Hero sections

entries.title: Border radius: 3xl (32px)
entries.description: Use: Full-width sections

entries.title: Border radius: full (9999px)
entries.description: Use: Pills, avatars

entries.title: Nested border radius: Outer = Inner + Padding
entries.description: Outer = Inner + Padding. inner xs (4) + padding xs (4) = outer sm (8); inner sm (8) + padding xs (4) = outer md (12); inner sm (8) + padding sm (8) = outer lg (16); inner md (12) + padding sm (8) = outer xl (20)

entries.title: Responsive spacing: reduce on mobile, increase on desktop
entries.description: Spacing should scale down on smaller screens to preserve content density and up on larger screens for breathing room. Use responsive Tailwind classes: section padding p-4 md:p-6 lg:p-8, card padding p-3 md:p-4 lg:p-6, grid gaps gap-4 md:gap-6 lg:gap-8, page margins px-4 md:px-8 lg:px-16. Reduce section spacing by one token level on mobile (gap-12 → gap-8). Never use the same large spacing values across all breakpoints.
entries.example: <section class='p-4 md:p-6 lg:p-8 space-y-4 md:space-y-6'>. Grid: gap-4 md:gap-6 lg:gap-8
entries.counterExample: Using p-8 at all breakpoints — wastes mobile screen real estate

entries.title: Standard spacing per component type
entries.description: Consistent internal spacing by component type: Cards: p-6 (24px padding), space-y-4 between content sections. Forms: space-y-4 between fields, gap-2 between label and input, gap-6 between form sections. Button groups: gap-2 (8px) for compact, gap-3 (12px) for standard. Tables: px-4 py-3 for cells, px-4 py-2 for header cells. Lists: space-y-2 for tight lists, space-y-3 for standard, divide-y for visual separation. Modals: p-6 for content, p-4 for footer with actions.
entries.example: Card: <div class='p-6 space-y-4'>. Form: <form class='space-y-4'>. Buttons: <div class='flex gap-3'>

entries.title: Spacing relationships: common element pairs
entries.description: Standard spacing between commonly paired elements. Icon ↔ text: gap-1 to gap-2 (4-8px). Label ↔ input: mb-2 (8px) or gap-2. Input ↔ helper text: mt-1 (4px). Input ↔ error message: mt-1 (4px). Section heading ↔ content: mb-4 (16px). Card ↔ card: gap-4 to gap-6 (16-24px). Section ↔ section: py-12 to py-16 (48-64px). Page header ↔ content: mb-6 to mb-8 (24-32px). Button ↔ button: gap-2 to gap-3 (8-12px). Avatar ↔ name: gap-2 to gap-3 (8-12px).
entries.example: Icon+text: <span class='flex items-center gap-2'>. Label+input: <div class='space-y-2'>. Sections: <div class='space-y-12'>

entries.title: Spacing decision guide: directly related → same group → separate → section
entries.description: Use this decision guide to pick the right spacing token. Directly related elements (icon + text, label + input): 4-8px (gap-1 to gap-2). Same logical group (fields in a form, items in a list): 12-16px (gap-3 to gap-4). Separate groups within a section (form sections, card groups): 24-32px (gap-6 to gap-8). Major page sections (hero → features → pricing): 48-64px (py-12 to py-16). The ratio between levels should be roughly 2:1 — if within-group is 16px, between-groups should be 32px.
entries.example: Form: label-input gap-2 (8px) → fields space-y-4 (16px) → sections space-y-8 (32px) → page sections py-16 (64px)

entries.title: Wizard/stepper spacing: step padding and navigation layout
entries.description: Multi-step wizards and steppers have specific spacing needs. Step indicator bar: py-4 with gap-2 between step dots/numbers, horizontal on desktop, simplified on mobile. Step content area: p-6 md:p-8 with consistent padding across all steps. Navigation buttons: pt-6 border-t with flex justify-between (Back on left, Next/Submit on right). Between steps: use smooth transitions, not abrupt layout shifts. Progress bar: mb-6 below step indicators, above content. Keep the wizard within max-w-2xl for focused attention.
entries.example:
steps
content
buttons
